--- "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." <jim_oflaherty_jr@...>
wrote:
> Ken,
> 
> I think I see your point.  However, if you only put
> in the head height input, you could end up with some
> ambulatory sequences that look very odd, but work
> okay; inverted knee walking, one hand one foot in
> odd jerky sequences, dog walking using all fours,
> crab walking using all fours, undulating body lying
> flat with stationary head, etc.
> 
> My guess is that some aspect of "balance",
> "symmetry" and "moderately constrained ranges of
> motion" (which will be quite challenging to define
> abstractly) will be desirable if the goal is to
> eventually have the resultant "figures" have some
> level of consistency and biological similarity, even
> to that of a dog, or horse, much less a human
> 
> If I am understanding your point, you are saying
> that achieving these ends might be more
> "efficiently" achieved without having to expand the
> input set dramatically to introduce all the addition
> information about muscle contraction and resistance
> combined with bone elasticity, bone connectivity,
> etc.

As you point out, there are many possible ways to
walk.  Which one you get will depend on the fitness
function.  If you want to get one which is very close
to what humans most commonly do, I think you need to
minimize energy usage by the muscles.  I'm guessing
that our most common walking style evolve to minimize
this important quantity.  We also have other styles of
walking.  For example, if your fitness function is to
minimize the sound made by the feet striking the
ground, while maintaining some minimum forward speed,
you should be able to evolve tip-toeing!

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
